subject: Sleep
title: Imagery Rehearsal Therapy
description: A micro-lesson that makes Imagery Rehearsal Therapy usable.

hook.text: What if you could rewrite the ending of a nightmare while you're awake and have it change in your sleep?

buildup.text: Imagery rehearsal therapy, or IRT, asks patients to recall a nightmare and then reimagine a positive ending.

discovery.text: The patient rehearses the new version multiple times while awake, imprinting it into memory.

twist.text: Over weeks, the brain begins incorporating the new ending into the actual dream. The nightmare changes.

climax.text: IRT reduces nightmare frequency by 50 to 70 percent in clinical studies, even for PTSD patients.

punchline.text: Rewrite the script while awake. Your dreams follow.

quiz.question: How does imagery rehearsal therapy reduce nightmares?
options: By reimagining the nightmare with a new positive ending
